Award.AwardTitle: EAGER: DG-SLAM: Differential Geometric Simultaneous Localization and Mapping

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Award.AbstractNarration:
The research objective of this project is to further the state-of-the-art in simultaneous localization and mapping (SLAM) methods for robotic vehicles. SLAM is the process of building a map of the surrounding vehicle environment while simultaneously localizing the vehicle relative to the map under construction. This work is motivated by cooperative control of small, agile, aerial robotic systems that are envisioned to execute tasks such as the transportation and manipulation of payloads using grippers or cables, assembly and construction of structures, and continuous surveillance and reconnaissance. The sensors these vehicles typically use are corrupted by bias and high-frequency noise. On-board computers are computationally limited as well. A computationally simple yet effective online SLAM algorithm that is immune to bias and noise typical of on-board sensors is crucial to the proliferation of autonomous robotic systems, and the focus of the proposed research.

This project focuses on theoretical advancements to DG-SLAM that will make it more practicable. Specifically, (a) how to account for measurement bias, and (b) how to use vector measurements directly, will be the focus of the proposed research. These two extensions of DG-SLAM are critical to the robustness, reliability, and ease of implementation of DG-SLAM on real-world vehicles.

POR.DRECONTENT:
For ground, air, or underwater robots to autonomously operate, three problems must be solved: the navigation problem, the guidance problem, and the control problem. The navigation problem answers the question "where am I,"  the guidance problem answers the question "where do I want to go,"  and the control problem answers the question "how do I get there."   Although autonomous operation of robotic vehicles requires solutions to all three problems, navigation is particularly important because control and guidance systems depend significantly on the quality of the navigation solution. Poor navigation will lead to poor control and guidance, which, in turn, leads to poor overall vehicle operation. 

The focus of the project was the development of provably convergent navigation methods for robotic vehicles. In particular, because the position and attitude of a robotic vehicle is mathematically an element of a matrix Lie group, navigation methods that adhere to the matrix Lie group structure of the problem were considered. The two major outcomes of this research were 1) a provably convergent simultaneous localization and mapping (SLAM) algorithm, and 2) a generalized nonlinear complementary filter, both of which are formulated on matrix Lie groups. A SLAM solution is required for operation of robotic vehicles in unknown environments. The developed generalized nonlinear complementary filter enables "higher-order" filtering that in turn can lead to better navigation solutions, including the SLAM solution.The proposed methods, in addition to having stability guarantees, are computationally simple, meaning they are well suited to on-board implementation on less capable robotic platforms.  Given the stability guarantees and relative simplicity of the navigation solutions developed, the solutions can be deployed on smaller, simpler, inexpensive, platforms while maintaining performance. Additionally, the solutions are appropriate for deployment on redundant back-up systems that use less computational resources when higher-level systems become compromised. As such, regarding the broader impact of this work, the proposed algorithms can help facilitate the use of smaller, inexpensive vehicles that can be used in more and more applications, individually or in teams, where before the cost of such systems was prohibitive.
